definition: to stand/to set up/to establish/to lay down/to draw up/at once/immediately

point/dot/drop/speck/o'clock/point (in space or time)/to draw a dot/to check on a list/to choose/to order (food in a restaurant)/to touch briefly/to hint/to light/to ignite/to pour a liquid drop by drop/(old) one fifth of a two-hour watch 更[geng1]/dot stroke in Chinese characters/classifier for items

sentences.english: I sink in deep mire, where there is no foothold.
sentences.chinese: 我身陷泥潭中，找不到立足點。

sentences.english: Fourthly, it finds solution to the centurial problem.
sentences.chinese: 它找到了破解世紀難題的立足點。

sentences.english: It is also encouraging the purchase and consumption of local produce, communicating its long-term benefits.
sentences.chinese: 從長遠的利益考慮，鼓勵自產自銷是基本立足點。

sentences.english: If you doubt yourself, then indeed you stand on shaky ground。(Ibsen, Norwegian dramatist)
sentences.chinese: 如果你懷疑自己，那麼你的立足點確實不穩固了。

sentences.english: The management is standard, It takes Shandong as foothold, face nation.
sentences.chinese: 經營管理規範，以山東爲立足點，面向全國。

sentences.english: Koopman takes this as the standpoint for his efficiency strategy.
sentences.chinese: 古浦邁先生也將此作爲了效率制勝策略的立足點。

sentences.english: Microsoft's Internet business has struggled to gain a foothold in China.
sentences.chinese: 微軟的互聯網業務一直努力想在中國獲得立足點。

sentences.english: If you doubt yourself , then indeed you stand on  shaky ground .(Ibsen , Norwegian dramatist )
sentences.chinese: 如果你懷疑自己，那麼你的立足點確實不穩固了。

sentences.english: Could he still rise and regain his footing in his conscience upon something solid?
sentences.chinese: 他還能直立起來並在他良心上找到堅實的立足點嗎？

sentences.english: And nation-building never gets a foothold here at home.
sentences.chinese: 國家的建設也從來沒有在國內獲得立足點。

definition: lit. pull one hair and the whole body moves/fig. a slight change will affect everything else/the butterfly effect
pinyin: qian1 yi1 fa4 er2 dong4 quan2 shen1

definition: (abbr. for 嘗試錯誤|尝试错误) trial and error/failure
(idiom) to use methods appropriate to the current situation
highest common factor HCF/greatest common divisor GCD
to assess one's income and spend accordingly (idiom); to live within one's means/You can only spend what you earn.
interregional/spanning two or more PRC provinces
